definition: Character, Controls, Camera: basically everything that has to do to how the payers are moving and interacting in the world.
An iterative approach to project management and software development that helps teams deliver value to their customers faster and with fewer headaches.
A set of rules or instructions specified in a sequence for solving problems or performing computations.

A historical action-adventure video game series by Ubisoft, depicting a fictional struggle between the Assassins, who fight for peace with free will, and the Templars, who desire peace through control.
Extremely large and complex datasets that cannot be easily managed or processed with traditional data-processing application software.
Google's annual flagship conference where they announce new products and share their vision for the future of cloud computing.
A European institution providing a unique, full-time paid MBA program for young engineers and scientists, combining strategic consulting missions in companies with high-level management education.
The study of computers and computational systems, including their theory, design, development, and application.
The process of inspecting, cleansing, transforming, and modeling data with the goal of discovering useful information, informing conclusions, and supporting decision-making.
An AI research laboratory owned by Google, responsible for major breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, including AlphaGo and the Gemini models.
A human-centered, iterative process for creative problem-solving. It involves empathizing with users, defining problems, ideating solutions, prototyping, and testing.
Community-run developer events, hosted by Google Developer Groups (GDG) around the globe, focused on community building and learning about Google's technologies.
A program that gives select partners and customers early access to new products or features to gather feedback before a public launch.
One of France's most prestigious 'grandes écoles' (elite higher education institutions), renowned for its excellence in research and education, particularly in the sciences and humanities.
The specific way in which players interact with a game, encompassing the rules, challenges, objectives, and the overall player experience.
A family of multimodal large language models developed by Google DeepMind, capable of understanding and processing text, images, audio, and video.
An official GitHub repository maintained by Google, containing code examples, tutorials, and guides to help developers get started with the Gemini API.
A type of artificial intelligence that can create new content, like text, images, or code, based on the data it was trained on.
A web-based platform for version control using Git. It is mostly used for computer code, allowing developers to collaborate on projects from anywhere.
A global program to recognize individuals who are experts and thought leaders in one or more Google technologies, who actively contribute to the developer and startup ecosystems.
A Google program that provides startups with resources, mentorship, and access to Google products and experts to help them grow.
A brand of smart speakers by Google. The devices enable users to speak voice commands to interact with services through Google Assistant. It also refers to the app used to control smart home devices.
A line of smart home products from Google including smart speakers, smart displays, streaming devices, thermostats, smoke detectors, and security systems.
A defunct cloud gaming service by Google, which allowed users to stream video games up to 4K resolution at 60 frames per second.

A prestigious group of highly selective higher education institutions in France, operating outside the main public university framework. They are renowned for training France's top engineers, scientists, civil servants, and business leaders.
An action-adventure video game developed by Ubisoft Quebec. The game follows Fenyx, a Greek soldier, on a quest to save the Greek gods from the titan Typhon.
A Google project using the same technology as Stadia to let Game studios build their own streaming platform.
A network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices over the internet.
A hands-on, in-person developer event from Google focused on applying Google's latest AI, Cloud, Web, and Mobile technologies.

Internet Protocol Television is the delivery of television content over Internet Protocol (IP) networks, as opposed to delivery through traditional terrestrial, satellite, and cable television formats.
A popular software application used for issue tracking and project management, widely used by agile development teams.
A methodology that adapts lean manufacturing principles to software development, focusing on eliminating waste and optimizing the development process.
An adaptation of lean manufacturing principles to the software development domain, focusing on optimizing the development process, eliminating waste, and delivering value to the customer efficiently.
An open-source, royalty-free connectivity standard for smart home devices, aiming to make them compatible with each other regardless of the manufacturer.
The practice of building, maintaining, and leveraging relationships with business partners to achieve mutual strategic goals.
The process of training, motivating and directing employees to optimize workplace productivity and promote professional growth.

Stands for 'Classes Préparatoires aux Grandes Écoles'. These are highly selective and intensive two-to-three-year post-secondary programs in France that prepare students for the competitive national exams required for admission into the prestigious 'Grandes Écoles'.
The business process of planning, developing, launching, and managing a product or service. It includes the entire lifecycle of a product, from ideation to end-of-life.

A professional role responsible for the development of products for an organization, owning the business strategy behind a product, specifying its functional requirements, and managing product releases.
The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
A technique to quickly create mockups or partially functional models of an application to gather early user feedback.
A framework within Agile that helps teams work together to develop, deliver, and sustain complex products, with a focus on specific roles, events, and artifacts.
A defunct cloud gaming service by Google, which allowed users to stream video games up to 4K resolution at 60 frames per second.
A low-power, IPv6-based wireless mesh networking protocol designed for Internet of Things (IoT) devices, enabling direct device-to-device and device-to-cloud communication.
A major French video game company, known for developing and publishing popular franchises like Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, and Watch Dogs.
User Experience. It encompasses all aspects of the end-user's interaction with a company, its services, and its products, with the goal of creating a seamless and enjoyable experience.
